content:
This was interesting. I had the shortest submission, but onl 71% right. I didn't have time to work out the bug for two of the tests. Coding it to step through all the possibilities while checking literally whether a*a-b*b==N doesn't seem very "shortest" friendly, though. 
Your provided solution, if I remove the comments and the extra function and reduce all names to 1 character, shows me 216 characters.
I kind of suspect you created this clash and just checked the boxes for both fastest and shortest without worrying much about the difference between them. 216 for Python is a lot of characters...
I couldn't fix the "binary" part, so at least I fixed that "language specific" part.

Dear authors and approvers. Please read the guidelines, especially this part:
Binary or language-specific outputs should be avoided in CoC.

Some output formats favor specific languages and make the contribution unbalanced. Binary outputs open the door to "cheating" solutions to get around 50%.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: With a small "n" I agree to approve this clash. If you add the restriction 0 <= b <= a <= n, I would agree to approve even with a large N.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A bit hard at first read but it's ok for Clash

In your solution you say : 0<=b**2<=a**2<=n
But that fail: N = 9
a**2 == 25
b**2 == 16
0<=16<=25<=9 ???????? 

How to solve this in brute force? This is a programming website, not a math website. If you can suggest a brute force solution that is solvable within the time limit, I appreciate it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems nice, not too hard, the naïve solution is a beginner-friendly

n = int(input())
print('true' if n&1 or not (n//2)&1 else 'false')

I'm pretty sure 'true' and 'false' aren't language-specific outputs. [1, 2, 3] might be an example of a language-specific output, since it's naively printed out by JavaScript if you have that array, but other languages may print out something else (more spaces or something idk)

For shortest, you get an advantage for thinking of the math solution.
"they do" if int(input())%4!=2 else "they don't"
is quite short

Hello, my first attempt was very similar to your brute_two_pointers, but I didn't know when to stop. For me 0 <= b <= a <= n is not intuitive, but with a small n, even if this restriction "0 <= b <= a <= n" is not known, it is possible to solve the problem.
